question.content: In which year Timur's invasion of Delhi took place?

solution.content: 1398. Timur: They invaded India during the reign of Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq. He nominated Khizr Khan (Sayyid Dynasty 1414 to 1451) to rule Punjab. Tughlaq Dynasty (1320 1414): Rulers Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq (founder), Muhammad bin Tughlaq, Firoz shah Tughlaq, and Muhammad Shah.

question.content: Which of the following was the last invasion by Mahmud Ghazni outside Punjab?

solution.content: Somnath Temple (attacked in 1025 AD). India was first invaded by Mahmud of Ghazni in 1001 AD and he defeated the army of Raja Jayapala. Foreign Invaders in India: Mohammed Bin Qasim (712 AD), Alexander's Invasion (326 BC), Invasion of Nadir Shah (1739), Mahmud Ghazni Attacked India 17 times.

question.content: Between who among the following did the Battle of Chandawar take place?

solution.content: Jaychand and Muhammad Ghori. Battle of Chandawar (1194): Fought at Chandawar (modern Firozabad). Jaychand (Gahadavala dynasty) was defeated and killed.

question.content: The famous Arabic scholar Al Biruni came into contact with India through in the eleventh century A.D.

solution.content: Mahmud Ghaznavi (998- 1030 AD) attacked India 17 times between 1000 to 1027 AD. His Important Invasions in India: In 1018, he plundered the holy city of Mathura and also attacked Kanauj (ruler Rajyapala); In 1025 he attacked Somnath. Al-Biruni's Books: Kitab-ul-Hind and Tahkik-e- Hind.

question.content: When did the Mongol ruler Genghis Khan die?

solution.content: 1227. Genghis Khan (1162- 1227) was the founder and first Great Khan of the Mongol Empire. He invaded India during the reign of Iltumish (3rd ruler of Mamluk dynasty). The Mongol Empire launched several invasions into the Indian subcontinent from 1221 to 1327.

question.content: Who among the following was the best-known Chahamana ruler?

solution.content: Prithviraj III (1168-1192). He defeated Sultan Muhammad Ghori in 1191 (first Battle of Tarain), But he was defeated by Ghori in 1192 (second Battle of Tarain). Vigraharaja II {(971-998), Chahamana dynasty). Prithviraj I {(1090 -1110), Chahamana dynasty). Vasudeva {(73 BCE to 28 BCE), founder of Kanvas dynasty).

question.content: In which year did the Mongols under Genghis Khan invade Transoxiana in North-East Iran?

solution.content: 1219. The Mongol conquest of Persia comprised three Mongol campaigns against Islamic states in the Middle East and Central Asia between 1219 and 1256. The Mongols had invaded the Delhi Sultanate a number of times, including in 1241, 1245, 1257, and 1285.

question.content: Zoroaster was a/an prophet.

solution.content: Iranian. Avesta, also called Zend-avesta, sacred book of Zoroastrianism containing its cosmogony, law, and liturgy, the teachings of the prophet Zoroaster (Zarathushtra).

question.content: Who among the following built the first European fort in India in the year 1503?

solution.content: Portuguese. Fort Emmanuel was built in 1503 by the Portuguese. Situated at Fort Kochi, it was once a symbol of the alliance between the ruler of Kochi and the monarch of Portugal. Delhi Sultanate

question.content: The office of Diwan-i-Insha dealt with which affair in administration?

solution.content: State correspondence. Delhi Sultanate Administration Diwan -i-Wizarat (Department of Revenue and Finance), Diwan-i-Arz (Department of Military), Diwan-i-Risalat (Department of Religious affairs), Diwan-i-bandagan (Department of slaves), Diwan-i-Khairat (Charity department), Diwan-i-mustakhraj (to realise arrears), Diwan- i-kohi (Department of agriculture).

question.content: Who was the Sultan of Delhi at the time of the establishment of Vijayanagara Empire?

solution.content: Mohammad bin Tughlaq Vijaynagar Empire: Established - 1336 by Harihara and Bukka. Capital - Hampi. The Empire stretched from Krishna river in the north to extreme south of the peninsula. Dynasties with first and last rulers Sangama Dynasty (Harihara I, Rajasekhara), Saluva Dynasty (Saluva Narasimha, Sadasiva), Tuluva Dynasty (Rama, Venkata), Aravidu Dynasty (Tirumala Raya, Sriranga III).

question.content: Which of the following systems of the Delhi sultanate had a influence on the Bahmani and Vijayanagar kingdoms? (b) Chahalgani

solution.content: Iqtadari System:- Introduced by Shamsuddin Illtutmish (3rd Sultan of Delhi). Provision - Under this system, the land of the empire was divided into several large and small tracts called Iqta and assigned these lqtas to his soldiers, officers and nobles. Administrative Terms used in Sultanate Period: Dabir (Secretary), Faujdar (Commander of army), Sipahsalar (Commander), Amil (Revenue officer), Diwan (Office: the central secretariat).

question.content: Who among the following was the head of the Diwan-i-Insha department under the Delhi sultanate?

solution.content: Dabir-i-Khas. Diwan -i-Bandagan - A slave department. Diwan-i-kohi - Agricultural department. Diwan-i-Mustakhraj - Arrears department. Barid-i-Mumalik - Head of the information and intelligence department. Amir-i-Dad - The law officer. Wakil-i-Dar - Controller of the royal household.

question.content: The Tomb of Razia Sultan in the state of Haryana is made of which building material?

solution.content: Baked bricks. Raziya sultan (1236 1240): Her tomb is situated in Kaithal (Haryana). She is the only female ruler ever to rule in the Delhi sultanate. Monuments built by Red sandstone: Qutub Minar, Red Fort and Humayun's Tomb. Taj mahal (white marble) - Tomb of Mumtaz Mahal.

question.content: During the Sultanate of Delhi, the term "Ulema" was associated with

solution.content: Learned theologians and Jurists. Officers in Delhi Sultanate - State Level: Amil (Revenue Officer), Barid (Intelligence agents), Khwaja (Accounts Officer), Kotwal (Head of city law and order), Muhatasib (Head of municipality law and order), Muftis (Expounder of law).

question.content: Who among the following was the daughter of Iltumish, a ruler of Slave Mamluk dynasty?

solution.content: Razia Sultan. In 1236, Razia Sultan (Mamluk dynasty), succeeded her father to the Sultanate of Delhi. She sent an expedition against Ranthambore to control the Rajputs. Mamluk dynasty (1206 to 1290) Founded by Qutbuddin Aibak (Lakh Baksh). He was succeeded by Iltutmish who was his son-in-law.

question.content: Under the Delhi Sultanate, a religious tax was imposed on the wealthy and rich Muslims in India.

solution.content: Zakat. Zakat tax was abolished by Sikander lodi. Firoz Shah Tughlaq introduced four types of taxes based on the Quran. They were Kharaj (Land tax), Khams (Tax on booty captured in war), Jizya (Imposed on non muslim), and Zakat.

question.content: In which year was Razia removed from the throne of the Delhi Sultanate?

solution.content: 1240. Razia Sultana (1236 -1240) married Malik Ikhtiar-ud-Altunia (the governor of Bhatinda under the rule of the Delhi Sultanate under Mamluk dynasty). She was killed on 15 October 1240 at Kaithal (Haryana). Tomb - Kaithal (Haryana).

question.content: Who composed Tabaqat-i-Nasiri in the Delhi Sultanate period? SSC CGL Tier II 02/03/2023

solution.content: "Tabaqat-i-Nasiri" (1260) was written by Minhaj-i-Siraj in Persian language. Hasan Nizami (Persian language poet) wrote Tajul-Maasir (the first official history of the Delhi Sultanate). Sufi poet Amir Khusro was the court poet of Alauddin Khilji. His famous works: Tughluq Nama, Wast-ul-Hayat, Nuh Sipihr, Ashiqa, Khamsa, Baqia-Naqia. Ziauddin Barani (Muslim political thinker of Delhi Sultanate) wrote Tarikh-i-Firozshahi and Fatwa-i-Jahandari.

question.content: Zafar khan was a famous General of which of the following rulers of the Delhi Sultanate? SSC CGL Tier II 03/03/2023

solution.content: Alauddin Khilji's Generals: Hizabruddin (Zafar Khan), Almas Beg (Ulugh Khan), Malik Kafur (Taj al-Din Izz al-Dawla), Nusrat Khan (Malik Nusrat Jalesari). Muhammad bin Tughlaq (Jauna Khan): Introduced token currency

question.content: Which of the following combinations of 'Ruler - Predecessor' is correct with respect to the Delhi Sultanate?

solution.content: Rulers of Khilji dynasty Jalaluddin Khalji (founder) Alauddin Khalji Qutb ud-Din Mubarak. Rulers of Tughlaq dynasty - Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq (founder) Muhammad bin Tughlaq Firoz Shah Tughlaq.

question.content: Who among the following rulers ruled before Prithviraj Chauhan over Delhi?

solution.content: Ananga Pala Tomar founded Delhi in 1052. An inscription of Vikram Samvat 1383 in the Delhi Museum confirms the founding of Delhi by the Tomars.

question.content: Who was the author of Tarikh - i- Mubarak Shahi which is a Persian language Sultanate? chronicle of thel

solution.content: Yahya bin Ahmad Sirhindi. Amir Khusrau (Books 'Tughlaq Nama', 'Nuh Sipihr', 'Khazain ul Futuh').

question.content: Who was the ruler of Delhi sultanate when lbn Batuta came to India?

solution.content: Muhammad Bin Tughlaq was the ruler of the Delhi sultanate when Ibn Batuta came to India. Muhammad bin Tughluq was the Sultan of Delhi from 1325 to 1351 from the Tughlaq Dynasty. Slave Dynasty

question.content: Mameluke style of architecture belongs to which dynasty?

solution.content: Slave dynasty (1206-1290) It is also known as the Mamluk Dynasty. Established by Qutbuddin Aibak. Capitals - Lahore (1206 - 1210). Famous buildings built by rulers of the slave dynasty: Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, Qutub Minar, Adhai Din ka Jhonpra, Tomb of Nasir-ud-Din Mohammed, Tomb of Shams-ud-Din Iltutmish.

question.content: The Delhi sultan, who succumbed to injuries as a result of his fall from horse, was

solution.content: Qutubuddin Aibak (Known as Lakh Baksh). He was the slave of Muhammad Ghori and was the first sultan of Delhi Sultanate. He established the slave dynasty (Mamluk dynasty). Famous Ruler of Slave Dynasty (1206 AD-1290 AD): Qutbuddin Aibak (1206-1210), Shamsuddin Iltutmish (1210-1236), Raziya Sultan (1236-1240), Balban (1266-1287).

question.content: The Tomb of Iltutmish was built in which year?

solution.content: 1235 AD. Iltutmish (Reign 1210-1236 AD) introduced silver coin (Tanka) and copper coin (Jital), and completed the construction of Qutub Minar. He also constructed a large reservoir Hauz-i-Sultani just outside Dehli-i-Kuhna.

question.content: Ghiyasuddin Balban introduced the customs of 'Sijda' and 'Paibos' as normal forms of salutations to the king as a part of_etiquette.

solution.content: Court. (d) Court

question.content: Who started the practice of celebrating Nauroz during the Delhi Sultanate period?

solution.content: Ghiyasuddin Balban. Nowruz is the Iranian New Year, also known as the Persian New Year. Ghiyasuddin Balban (1266-1287) was the first Sultan of Delhi to introduce the practice of 'Sijda' (prostration) and Paibos (kissing the feet of monarch) as the normal form of Salutation of the king.

question.content: Balban served as naib to which of the following sultans of Delhi?

solution.content: Nasiruddin Mahmud (1246-1266 AD) Eighth ruler of Slave dynasty (Mamluk dynasty). Minhaj -i-Siraj was his court historian. Balban (1266-1287 AD): He pursued the policy of 'blood and iron'. He established the department of military (Diwan-i-Ariz). Razia Sultan (1236-1240 AD): First muslim woman to rule over Delhi sultanate.

question.content: lltutmish introduced a copper coin called in place of the silver coin.

solution.content: Jittal. Shamsuddin Iltutmish was the third Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate. He introduced the Chahalgani system. He coined tanka (Silver) and Jittal (Copper).

question.content: Who among the following revolted against Balban, Sultan of Delhi, and declared himself as an independent ruler of Bengal in 1279?

solution.content: Tughril Beg. Balban (Mamluk dynasty or Slave Dynasty) introduced the practice of Sijda (prostration) and paibos (kissing the feet of monarch). Ghiyas-ud-Din Balban appointed his own son Bughra khan as governor of Bengal. Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq also known as Nasiruddin, was the last sultan of the Tughlaq dynasty.

question.content: Who occupied Badaun (A.D. 1197-98) and appointed Iltutmish as its first Muslim Governor?

solution.content: Qutbuddin Aibak (1206- 1210 (First ruler of Slave Dynasty /Mamluk Dynasty)}: He established the first Muslim dynasty and was also known as Lakh Baksh. He died in Lahore, Pakistan after falling from a horse ride.

question.content: Qutub Minar is an example of _ architecture.

solution.content: Indo Islamic. Indo-Islamic architecture is the architecture of the Indian subcontinent produced for Islamic patrons and purposes. Famous Examples City of Mandu (Madhya Pradesh), Taj Mahal (Agra), Gol Gumbaz (Karnataka), Jama Masjid (Delhi) etc. Dravidian architecture Examples Brihadeshwara temple, Annamalaiyar Temple, Meenakshi temple, Airavatesvara temple etc.

question.content: Who had assumed the title of Balban? SSC CGL Tier II (07/03/2023)

solution.content: Ulugh Khan.

question.content: Minhaj-i-Siraj was a chronicler during the rule of

solution.content: Iltutmish (ruler of Slave dynasty). Minhaj-i-Siraj was a 13th-century Persian historian. He worked as a teacher in a madrasa under Nasiruddin Qubacha. During Razia Sultan's reign, he was appointed as principal of Madrasa in Delhi. During the reign of Muiz ud-Din Bahram, he was appointed to the post of Chief Qazi. During the reign of Nasiruddin Mahmud, he was made a court poet. He dedicated his work 'Tabaqat-e-Nasiri' to Nasiruddin Mahmud. He died in Delhi, during the reign of Balban.

question.content: Quwwat al-Islam mosque and minaret, built during the last decade of the _ century.

solution.content: Twelfth. Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque (1192-1198) built by Qutubuddin Aibak. Other Monuments of Qutub complex Alai Darwaza (by Ala-ud-din Khalji in 1311 AD). Tomb of Iltutmish (1235). Tomb of Imam Zamin (1537).

question.content: What is the approximate height (in metres) of the Qutub Minar situated in Delhi ?

solution.content: 73 (237.8 ft). Qutub Minar has five storeys. It was started in 1199 by Qutb ud-Din Aibak, completed in 1220 by his son-in-law Iltutmish. UNESCO (1993). Other Important Minars Charminar, Hyderabad (1591) by Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah, height is 48.7 m (160 ft). Chand Minar - height 64 m (210 ft) built by Ala-ud-din Bahmani in Daultabad, Maharashtra.

question.content: Who among the following was the Wazir of Sultan Iltutmish?

solution.content: Nizam ul-Mulk Junaidi. Iltutmish is known as the real founder of Delhi Sultanate who occupied the throne in 1210 AD after KIilling Aram Bakshsh. He shifted his capital from Lahore to Delhi.

question.content: Ghiyasuddin Balban, ruler of the Slave dynasty, took up the title of

solution.content: Zil-i-llahi (shadow of God). Ghiyas ud din Balban Abolished Chahalghani (Council of 40 nobles), Introduced Persian customs as sizdah (prostration), paibos (kissing feet of sultan), established Diwan-i-Ariz (defence department).

question.content: Which of the following is the correct chronological order of early Turkish rulers who ruled over Delhi from the year 1206 to 1290?

solution.content: Qutubuddin Aibak, Shamsuddin Illtutmish, Raziyaa. Chronological order of the rulers is Qutb ud-Din Aibak (founder) → Aram Shah→ Iltutmish → Rukn-ud-din Feroze → Razia al-Din → Muiz-ud-din Bahram - Ala-ud-din Masud → Nasiruddin Mahmud → Ghiyas-ud-din Balban Muiz-ud-din Muhammad Qaiqabad.

question.content: In which of the following forts was Razia Sultan imprisoned by Malik Ikhtiyar-ud-din Altunia?

solution.content: Qila Mubarak in Bathinda, built by Raja Dab. Jaigarh fort in Jaipur was built in 1726 AD by Jai Singh II. Golconda fort in Golconda was built by Qutb Shahi dynasty. Mehrangarh fort in Jodhpur was built by Rao Jodha. Khilji Dynasty

question.content: Who among the following Sultans framed a series of regulations to weaken the power of nobles?

solution.content: Alauddin Khilji (Khilji Dynasty 1290-1320): He made nobles pay land tax for their holdings. This curbed the excess of wealth owned by nobles. The nobles were also ordered not to have social gatherings or intermarriages without his permission. The group of nobles, called "The Forty".

question.content: Who among the following classical poets of the Sultanate period in India popularized Qawwali, a form of music which derived its name from the Arabic word 'qaul', meaning 'to speak'?

solution.content: Amir Khusrau - He was also known as Tuti-e-Hind (Parrot of India). He was the court musician of Alauddin Khilji. He also lived in courts of different rulers such as Balban, Muhammad, Cakubad, Jalaluddin Khilji, Mubarak Shah Khaliji, and Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq. He was also a disciple of Nizammuddin Auliya.

question.content: Which of the following Sultans of Delhi was appointed as Amir-i-Tuzuk (Master of Ceremonies) before becoming the Sultan?

solution.content: Alauddin Khalji (1296- 1316). He was the second ruler of Khilji dynasty after Jalaluddin Khilji (Founder - 'Khalji Dynasty'). He was also appointed Arizi-i-Mumalik (Minister of War) during the reign of Jalaluddin Khilji and laid the foundation of his capital Siri in 1303 A.D.

question.content: Who was the first to mention the incident of Jauhar in Persian?

solution.content: Amir Khusrau. 'Jauhar' - The collective self-immolation by women in order to escape capture and forced into slavery by invaders in face of imminent defeat. In 1303, Alauddin Khilji laid the size of Chittor.

question.content: Who among the following was the slave-general Alauddin Khilji, who led his army in the battle against Ramachandra of Devagiri?

solution.content: Malik Kafur - Also known as 'Hazar Dinari' Was a slave of the Delhi Sultanate ruler Ala-ud-din Khilji (1296-1316). Alauddin Khilji - second sultan of Khilji dynasty. Important Military Campaigns Gujarat (1299), Ranthambore (1301), Chittor (1303), Malwa (1305) and Jalore (1311). Administrative Reforms implemented the system of "dagh Pratha," branding horses, and "Huliya Pratha (a system of ranks)" keeping records of soldiers.

question.content: During Alauddin Khilji's reign, the cloth market was known as_

solution.content: Sarai-i-Adl (Place of justice). Alauddin Khilji, under his market policy, built three markets of foodgrain, precious clothes and slave cattle near Kushke Sabz (Hara Rajmahal) within the Badaun gate in Delhi. These were government- aided markets.

question.content: Who was the first Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate to start military expeditions into southern India?

solution.content: Alauddin Khalji (1296-1316):- He was the second ruler of the Khilji dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate. Battles related to Alauddin Khilji: Gujarat Vijay: (1299) Karna rescued himself and his family to Devagiri. Ranthambore Vijay: (1301) Chauhan King Hammir Dev defeated Sultan Alauddin Khilji, under Nusrat Khan. Chittor Vijay: (1303) Alauddin Khalji defeated Raja Ratan singh.

question.content: Who among the following was the founder of the Khilji Dynasty?

solution.content: Jalal-ud-din Firoz Khilji. Hе ascended to the throne in 1290 AD after deposing Qutbuddin Mubarak Shah, the last ruler of the Slave Dynasty.

question.content: Which monument of Khilji dynasty in Delhi has the utilization of red sandstone?

solution.content: Alai Darwaza. Built by Allaudin Khilji the Sultan of Delhi in 1311 AD. Moti Masjid - Aurangzeb (Delhi). Victoria memorial - George V (Kolkata). Charminar - Mohammed Quli Qutub Shah (Hyderabad).

question.content: Which officer under Alauddin Khilji was required to maintain a register of merchants to ensure an adequate supply of goods? SSC CGL Tier II (06/03/2023)

solution.content: Shahna-i-Mandi. Alauddin set up three markets at Delhi First for food-grains, the second for cloth, sugar, ghee, oil, dry fruits and the third for horses, slaves and cattle. Diwan-e Riyasat - Head of Market. The prices of all varieties of grains were fixed by the first regulation or Zabita. Munhiyans Secret agents under Allauddin. Parwana Rais - Permit officer under Allauddin.

question.content: How many types of taxes were in the reign of the ruler Alauddin Khalji?

solution.content: 3 types of taxes: Jaziya (religious tax on Hindu community), Ghari tax (tax on Houses), and Chari tax (tax on cattles). He resisted the Mongol invasion more than 12 times. He followed the Divine Right Theory of Kingship. He was the first to bring the standing army system. He died in 1316 A.D. Tughlaq Dynasty

question.content: Who among the following was the successor of Muhammad-Bin Tughlaq to the throne?

solution.content: Firuz Shah Tughlaq (1351 1388). He was known as the father of the irrigation approach in India. Diwan -e-Khairat which was built for collecting money for charitable work. He imposed Jizya upon the Brahmins and made it a separate tax. Tughlaq Dynasty (1320 A.D - 1414 A.D) Founder Ghiyas-ud-din Tughluq (Ghazi Malik).

question.content: Who amongst the following raised the banner of revolt against Nasiruddin Khusrau?

solution.content: Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq or Ghazi malik (1320-1325 AD) He was the governor of Punjab during the reign of Allauddin khilji. He was the founder of the Tughlaq dynasty who fought against Mongols, and started Tughlaqabad Fort construction.

question.content: Who among the following appointed Aziz Khummar a wine distiller to high administrative post?

solution.content: Muhammad bin Tughluq (1324-1351) - He was the eldest son of Ghiyasuddin Tughluq (founder of the Tughlaq dynasty). He appointed Firuz Hajjam a barber, Mank a Tabbakh a cook, and two gardeners Ladha and Pira, to high administrative posts. He also decided to transfer his capital from Delhi to Devagiri (Daulatabad).

question.content: Ziyauddin Barani wrote his chronicle first in 1356 and another version_ years later.

solution.content: Two. Ziauddin Barani (1285-1358 CE) wrote his chronicle first in 1356 and wrote another version two years later. He was a Muslim political thinker of the Delhi Sultanate during Muhammad bin Tughlaq and Firuz Shah's reign. Other Books: Tarikh-i-Firoz Shahi and Fatwa-i-Jahandari, Sana-i- Muhammadi, Tarikh-i-Barmaki, etc.

question.content: Who among the following Moroccan travellers came to India during the reign of Muhammad bin Tughlaq?

solution.content: lbn Battuta (Moroccan traveler) came to India during the reign of Muhammad bin Tughlaq in 1333-1347. Book: Rihla. Abd-al-Razzaq visited Vijaynagar Kingdom during the reign of Deva Raya II (Sangama dynasty). Al-Masudi (Herodotus of the Arabs) visited India around 10th century AD. Suleiman al-Tajiri visited India around the 9th century during the Pala empire.

question.content: Which of the following is the correct chronological order of the rulers of the Tughlaq dynasty who ruled over Delhi from the year 1320 to 1414?

options.text: Ghiyasuddin Tugmuq, Firuz Shah Tughluq, Muhammad Tughluq
Firuz Shah Tughluq, Muhammad Tughluq, Ghiyasuddin Tughluq
Ghiyasuddin Tughluq, Muhammad Tughluq, Firuz Shah Tughluq
Muhammad Tughluq, Firuz Shah Tughluq, Ghiyasuddin Tughluq

answer: Ghiyasuddin Tughluq, Muhammad Tughluq, Firuz Shah Tughluq

solution.content: 1320-1324 (Ghiyas-ud-din Tughlaq; Founder of Tughlaq dynasty) 1324-1351 (Muhammad ibn Tughluq) 1351-1388 (Firuz Shah Tughlaq) (Muhammad Shah).

question.content: Who among the following founded the city of Tughlaqabad?

solution.content: Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq (Ghazi Malik). He founded the Tughlaq dynasty in 1320. He replaced men with horses in the courier system. He started Dawk chowkies. His son Jaunakhan ascended the throne and took the title Muhammad bin Tughlaq

question.content: Which Sultan established a separate department (Diwan-i-Amir Kohi) to take care of agriculture?

solution.content: Muhammad Bin Tughlaq established a separate department (Diwan-i-Amir Kohi) to take care of agriculture. This department was headed by officer Amir-e-Kohi with the aim to improve the condition of cultivation in doab. Sayyid Dynasty

question.content: Who was the first ruler of the Sayyid Dynasty?

solution.content: Khizr Khan (In 1414 A.D) - He captured the Delhi sultanate from the Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq (Tughlaq dynasty) and founded the Sayyid Dynasty. He was succeeded by Mubarak Shah (first Sultan ruler to appoint Hindu nobles in the court of Delhi) and constructed "Mubarakbad" City. Ala-ud-din Shah - Last ruler of Sayyid dynasty. Rulers- Khizr Khan Sayyid → Mubarak Shah →Muhammad Shah Ala-ud-Din Shah. Lodi Dynasty

question.content: Which of the following mosques/masjids was built during the reign of Lodi dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate?

solution.content: Moth ki Masjid, Delhi. It was built in 1505 by Wazir Miya Bhoiya. Begumpuri mosque (Delhi) It was constructed by Muhammad Tughluq. Quwwat al-Islam (Delhi) It was constructed by Qutub-Ud-din Aibak. Lal Masjid (Delhi) It was built by the Mughal emperor during Akbar's regime.

question.content: "Double Dome" feature of Indo-Islamic architecture was introduced by which dynasty of Delhi Sultanate?

solution.content: Lodi Dynasty (1451-1526). It was the fifth and final dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate and was founded by Bahlul Khan Lodi when he replaced the Sayyid dynasty. Double dome built of two layers. There is one layer inside which provides a ceiling to the interior of the building. The other layer is the outer one which crowns the buildings. Example - Humayun's Tomb.

question.content: Who was the last sultan of the Lodi Dynasty?

solution.content: Ibrahim Khan Lodi (1517-1526 AD) was the last Sultan of the Lodi Dynasty (1451 to 1526). The first battle of Panipat (1526 AD) - Babar defeated and killed Ibrahim Lodi. The tomb of Ibrahim Lodi is in Panipat (Haryana).

question.content: Bahlol Lodi was succeeded by his son _ under the title of Sultan Sikandar Shah in 1489.

solution.content: Nizam Khan {assumed the title Sikandar Shah,founded Agra in 1504, relocated the capital from Delhi to Agra, pen name Gulrukh). Bahlul Lodi {founder of Lodi Dynasty, Conquered Gwalior, Samthal, Sakit and Mewat, died in 1489 A.D}. emperor Jahangir) built "Pathar Ki Masjid" on the banks of River Ganga, Patna (Bihar) in 1621.

question.content: On 12 August emperor the Mughal appointed the East India Company as the Diwan of Bengal.
The _ sultanate is ruled by the

solution.content: The Jaunpur sultanate was ruled by the sharqi dynasty. It was founded by Khwajah-i-Jahan Malik Sarwar in 1394. In 1479, Sultan Hussain Khan was defeated by the forces of Afghan chieftain Bahlul Lodhi and this dynasty came to an end. Mughal Period

question.content: Who among the following was given the charge of looking after the imperial household during the Mughal administration?

solution.content: Mir Saman. Mir Bahri (mir-i-bahr) Responsible for the maintenance of the river and seaports. Mir Bakshi - Headed military department, nobility, information and intelligence agencies. Mir-e-aatish Head of the ordinance department.

Agrahara (Agraharam, Ghatoka, Boya) refers to the land, village, or fields that were given to Brahmans.

question.content: Nagabhata was the king of which of the following dynasty?

solution.content: Pratihara dynasty. Nagabhata ruled from 730 - 760 CE. Capital of Pratihara dynasty: first Ujjain then Kannauj. Kakatiya dynasty (Founder: Rudradeva- 1). Vardhana dynasty {founder: Pushyabhuti). Reddi kingdom {Prolaya Vema Reddi).

question.content: The craftspersons of Bidar were so famed for their inlay work in

solution.content: Copper and Silver. Work of Bidar (Karnataka) craftsperson called Bldri. Bidar was the capital of Bahmani Kingdom in the 14th century. Bidar fort was built by Ahmad Shah Wali Bahman. Bidar is also considered one of the holiest places for Sikh pilgrimage.

question.content: In 1342, one of the nobles, Haji Ilyas Khan united Bengal and became its ruler under the title of and laid the foundation of the llyas Shah dynasty.

solution.content: Shams-ud-din llyas Shah {(founder of Bengal Sultanate and llyas Shahi dynasty (First dynasty of Bengal)). Dynasties of Bengal Sultanate - Ilyas Shahi (1342-1415), Ganesha (1414 -1435), Restorer of llyas Dynasty (Nasiruddin Mahmud Shah-l, 1435 -1487), Habshi rule (Shahzada Barbak, 1487-1494) and Hussain Shahi dynasty (Alauddin Hussain Shah - 1494-1519).

question.content: Which Bahmani ruler granted the title of 'Chief of the Merchants' or Malikut-Tujjar to Mahmud Gawan?

solution.content: Humayun Shah (1458 - 1461) Ala-ud-Din Bahman Shah founded Bahmani Kingdom in 1347. Gulbarga Fort in Karnataka was built by him. Mohammed Shah I was the 2nd ruler of the Bahmani Sultanate. Tajuddin Feroz Shah (Bahmani Kingdom) is famous for conquering Raichur Daob from Vijayanagar Kingdoms.

question.content: Who was the architect of the famous Mysore Palace in Karnataka?

solution.content: Henry Irwin. Mysore Palace (also known as Amba Villas) is a historical palace at Mysore in Karnataka. It was the official residence of the Wadiyar dynasty. Mysore Palace was constructed in Indo-Saracenic style architecture.

question.content: The Vimana in the Dravidian style of temple architecture is usually in which shape?

solution.content: Pyramidal. Gopuram (entrance gateway in the center of the front wall). Antarala (vestibular tunnel), garbhagriha (the innermost sanctuary of a Hindu and Jain temple). Famous Dravidian Temples Rajarajeswara or Brihadeshwara temple (Rajaraja Chola at Thanjavur), Gangaikondacholapuram temple (Rajendra I), Annamalaiyar Temple (Tiruvannamalai, Tamil Nadu), Meenakshi Temple (Tamil Nadu), Airavatesvara Temple (Tamil Nadu) etc.

question.content: Most Mughal buildings are constructed material? using which building

solution.content: Red sandstone. Features of Mughal Architecture: a mix of Indian, Persian, and Turkish architectural styles, building materials (red sandstone and white marble), Charbagh gardens, arabesque, geometric patterns on pillars and walls, large entrances, and magnificent calligraphy.

question.content: Consider the following statements about a fort: 1. It was originally known as Mankal. 2. It was built on a hilltop in 1143. In the above mentioned sentences, forts is being talked about?

solution.content: Golconda fort (Hyderabad; Built by the Qutb shahi dynasty). Chitradurga fort (Karnataka; built by the Chalukyas and Hoysalas, later the Nayakas of Chitradurga of the Vijayanagar Empire. Daulatabad fort (Maharashtra; built by Yadava dynasty), and Aguada Fort (Goa; built by Portuguese).

question.content: The temples of Khajuraho are a magnificent example of the of the temple.

solution.content: Nagara style. Basically, there are 3 kinds of temple architecture: Nagara Style, Dravida Style, and Vesara Style. Examples of Nagara-style temples in India are- Khajuraho temples in MP, Kandariya Mahadev Temple in Madhya Pradesh, Sun temple at Konark, Sun temple at Modhera, Gujarat, and Ossian temple in Gujarat, etc.

question.content: Which of the following is a famous example of a temple built in complete Dravidian style?

solution.content: Kailash Temple at Ellora was built by Krishna I of the Rashtrakuta Dynasty. King Narasimhadeva built Konark temple. Kandariya Mahadeo temple was built by Vidyadhara a powerful Chandela king. Kamakhya temple was built by the Mlechchha dynasty. Rebuilt by Koch King Nara Narayan and Ahom kings.

question.content: The ancient Neemrana Baori is located in which of the following districts of Rajasthan?

solution.content: Alwar. Famous Baori in India Chand Baori (Rajasthan), Agrasen Ki Baoli (New Delhi), Rani ki Vav (Gujarat), Pushkarani (Karnataka), Baoli Ghaus Ali Shah (Haryana), Mata Bhavani ni Vav (Gujarat), Rajon ki Baoli (New Delhi), Surya Kund (Gujarat).

question.content: Which of the given statements related to the temples of India is correct? I. The Nagara style of architecture is also known as the North Indian style II. The Dravidian style of architecture is also known as the South Indian style.

solution.content: Both I and II. Different styles of Temple architecture in India Nagara or the north Indian temple style→ Rekha-prasada/Latina, Phamsana, and Valabhi; Dravida Or South Indian Temple Style → Kuta or Caturasra, Shala or Ayatasra, Gaja-prishta or vrittayata, Vritta, and Ashtasra.

question.content: Tipu Sultan became the ruler of Mysore in _

solution.content: December 1782. Tipu Sultan (Tiger of Mysore) succeeded his father Hyder Ali as the Ruler of Mysore. The Mysore Palace was the residence of the Wodeyar Dynasty.

question.content: Who among the following was given the title of 'Uttarapatha Swamin'?

solution.content: Dharmapala assumed the title of Uttarapatha Swamin, Parama Bhattaraka, Paramesvara, and Maharajadhiraja. He was the successor of Gopala (founder of the Pala empire). He was a pious Buddhist. He founded Vikramshila University in Bhagalpur, Bihar.

question.content: Which of the following was an integral part of the Indo-Islamic form of architecture?

solution.content: Dome (large hemispherical roof), arch, and Muqarnas vault. Styles of Indo-Islamic Architecture: The Imperial Style (Delhi sultanate); The Provincial styles (Mandu, Gujarat, Bengal, and Jaunpur); The Mughal Style (Delhi, Agra, and Lahore); The Deccani style (Bijapur and Golconda).

question.content: Who was the ruler of Mysore in 1761 ?

solution.content: Hyder Ali. In 1769, he defeated the British forces several times and reached the Madras walls. In the second Anglo-Mysore War, he died in 1782 and was succeeded by his son Tipu.

question.content: What was the capital of the Satavahana Dynasty (60 BC-225 AD)?

solution.content: Pratishthana. Satavahanas (Simuka was the founder) succeeded the Mauryas in Deccan and in Central India. They had two capitals one was Pratishthana (modern Paithan) on the Godavari in Aurangabad district and the second one was Amravati.

question.content: The Mughal emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar died in

solution.content: 1862. Bahadur Shah Zafar was a titular Emperor, as the Mughal Empire existed in name only and his authority was limited only to the walled city of Old Delhi (Shahjahanabad). Following his involvement in the Indian Mutiny of 1857, the British exiled him to Rangoon in British-controlled Burma in 1858, after convicting him on several charges.

question.content: In 1590, the Govind Deva temple of Vrindavan, near Mathura was constructed from sandstone.

solution.content: Red. The Govind Deva temple was built by the king of Jaipur, Man Singh, in 1590 in Vrindavan in Uttar Pradesh.

question.content: The book 'Man Kautuhal' was compiled by which of the following kings of Medieval India?

solution.content: Raja Mansingh Tomar. He was the ruler of Gwalior. He was a patron of the Dhrupad genre from Hindustani Classical Music. He built Gwalior fort (Gujari Mahal and Man Mandir Palace). The founder of the Tomar dynasty in India was Anangapala I.

question.content: King Lalitaditya Muktapida ruled over

solution.content: Kashmir. Ahmad Shah I was the first independent sultan of Gujarat, who founded Ahmedabad (1411).The Chogyal (king who governs with righteousness) Palden Namgyal Thodup was crushed in 1975 and Sikkim merged with India as its 22nd state. King Mahabali ruled over Kerala.

question.content: During the rule of which dynasty were Nalanda and Vikramashila universities founded?

solution.content: The Palas. Kumargupta founded Nalanda University in the 5th century A.D. Vikramashila was established by the Pala emperor Dharmapala

question.content: Chandannagar was established as a French colony in 1673, obtaining permission from the then Nawab of Bengal, to establish a trading post on the right bank of the river Hooghly.

solution.content: Ibrahim Khan. French Colonies In India- Pondicherry, Karaikal, Yanam (Andhra Pradesh) on the Coromandel Coast, Mahe on the Malabar Coast and Chandernagor in Bengal.

question.content: Hafız (Hafez) was a _ century poet whose collection of poems is known as 'Diwan' or 'Diwan-e-Hafiz'.

solution.content: 14th-century'. Hafez was an Iranian poet. His collection of poems 'Diwan' is in Persian language. Most of the parts of 'Diwan' are Ghazals.

question.content: In the context of Sufi traditions, what is the meaning of the word 'sama'?

solution.content: recitation of sacred songs. Sufism (tasawwuf) is a mystic sect of Islam that emphasizes introspection and spiritual closeness with God. They believe in inner purity rather than external conduct and rituals.

question.content: was one of the first Indian rulers to lead an armed rebellion against the British East India Company in 1824 against the implementation of the Doctrine of Lapse.

solution.content: Kittur Chennamma was one of the first Indian rulers to lead an armed rebellion against the British East India Company in 1824 against the implementation of the Doctrine of Lapse.

question.content: Which of the following cities became the capital of Bahamani sultanate immediately after its foundation?

solution.content: с) Ahsanabad. Bahamani Sultanate (Sunni Muslim empire that ruled the Deccan) Founded in 1347 by Ala' al-Din Bahman Shah. Between 1490 and 1518 dissolved into the five successor powers of Bijapur, Ahmadnagar, Golconda, Berar, and Bidar.

question.content: Vikramaditya VI, whose biography was composed by his court poet Bilhana, was a ruler of _ dynasty.

solution.content: Chalukya. Vikramaditya VI, whose biography was composed by his court poet Bilhana, was a ruler of Chalukya dynasty. The Chalukya dynasty was established by Pulakeshin I in 543 AD.

question.content: 'Rang Ghar', one of Asia's oldest amphitheatres, was built by the king of the_dynasty.

solution.content: Ahom Dynasty. Rang Ghar, constructed by the Ahom King Swargadeo Promotta Singha.

question.content: Who among the following was the founder of the Bhakti sect named 'Pushtimarg'?

solution.content: Vallabhacharya founded the Krishna-centered PushtiMarg sect of Vaishnavism in the Braj region of India, and the philosophy of Shuddha advaita (Pure Nondualism). Pushtimarg is a form of Krishna worship for adoration.

question.content: Who among the following was the founder of the Suryavamsi Gajapati dynasty that ruled parts of Orissa and Andhra Pradesh in the 15th century?

solution.content: Kapilendra Deva was the founder of the Suryavamsi Gajapati dynasty that ruled parts of Orissa and Andhra Pradesh in the 15th century (1434-66 СЕ).

question.content: Which city was the capital of the French Colony in India?

solution.content: Pondicherry. Five French colonies are Pondicherry, Karaikal in Tamil Nadu and Yanaon in Andhra Pradesh on the Coromandel Coast, Mahe in Kerala on the Malabar Coast and Chandernagore in West Bengal.

question.content: Who among the following was the Nizam of Hyderabad in 1947?

solution.content: Osman Ali. He was the last Nizam (ruler) of the Princely State of Hyderabad. He ruled the Kingdom of Hyderabad between 1911 and 1948.

question.content: Which of the following is the meaning of 'Pishtaq' in the context of medieval Indo-Islamic Architecture?

solution.content: tall gateway. Pishtaq is a Persian/Farsi word that means 'front of arch'. It is a rectangular frame around an arched opening of a building like mosques and palaces.

question.content: Prophet Muhammad founded the faith of Islam in the_ century.

solution.content: Seventh century. Islam is the 2nd largest religion in the world. Largest religion - Christianity.

question.content: Who among the following was appointed as the curator of ancient monuments in 1880?

solution.content: HH Cole. He was a British civil servant and inventor who facilitated many innovations in commerce and Education.

question.content: Which of the following dynasties made Kanauj (Kanyakubja) its capital city?

solution.content: Pratihara dynasty was an imperial power during the Late Classical period on the Indian subcontinent that ruled much of Northern India from the mid-8th to the 11th century. They ruled first at Ujjain and later at Kannauj.

question.content: Which part of India did the Nizams of Asaf Jahi dynasty rule?

solution.content: Deccan provinces. The Asaf Jahi was a Muslim dynasty that ruled the Kingdom of Hyderabad. It was founded by Nizam al-Mulk who was intermittently viceroy of the Deccan (peninsular India) under the Mughal emperors from 1713 to 1721 and who resumed the post again under the title Aşaf Jah in 1724.

question.content: Who among the following was a Portuguese writer who wrote about the trade and society in South India?

solution.content: Duarte Barbosa was the Portuguese writer who visited India during (1500-1516) and wrote about the trade and society in South India in his manuscript, 'The Book of Duarte Barbosa.

question.content: Who among the following foreign travellers is NOT correctly matched with their respective country they hail from?

solution.content: Peter Mundy (Britain) was a seventeenth-century British merchant trader, traveller and writer. He was the first Briton to record, in his Itinerarium Mundi, tasting Chaa (tea) in China and travelled extensively in Asia, Russia and Europe.

question.content: Who among the following was the first Portuguese viceroy of India?

solution.content: Francisco de Almeida was the first Portuguese viceroy of India in 1505. Нe was given the credit of Portuguese possession in India. His policy was to maintain a strong naval army over the Indian ocean.

question.content: Who among the following did NOT belong to the Rajput kingdom of Marwar?

He Built Vijaya Stambha (dedicated to lord Vishnu) within Chittor Fort in 1448 to commemorate his victory over the army of Malwa led by Mahmud Khalji in the Battle of Sarangpur.

question.content: Kalinjar Fort, which was strategically important during medieval times, is located in:

solution.content: Uttar Pradesh (Banda district). Kalinjar Fort Built by the Chandelas. Main attraction of Kalinjar is the Neelkanth Temple built by Chandela ruler Paramaditya Dev.

question.content: In which year Sanchi was discovered after being abandoned for nearly 600 years?

solution.content: 1818. t was discovered in 1818 by General Taylor. Sanchi is a Buddhist complex, famous for its Great Stupa, on a hilltop at Sanchi Town in Raisen District of the State of Madhya Pradesh, India.

question.content: Who was the Governor General of Bengal during the 3rd Anglo-Mysore war?

solution.content: 2nd Earl Cornwallis. The resultant war lasted three years and was a resounding defeat for Mysore.

question.content: In which year did the Portuguese capture Goa?

solution.content: 1510 AD. Portuguese Governor Afonso de Albuquerque captured Goa (became the capital of the Portuguese) from the Adil Shahis. The Portuguese were the first European to come (1498) and the last one to leave India (1961).
